title: No Data, No Worries : Fabricatr
text:
Motivation



Rarely work on my own data.
Literate, reproducible workflow

Org-Babel
RMarkdown
Quarto.

Scripts to clean, summarise, plot and analyse data.





The Turing Way project illustration by Scriberia. Used under a CC-BY 4.0 licence. DOI: 10.5281/zenodo.3332807




::: {.notes} Speaker Notes can be added to each slide. Formatting can be used here too. :: : ## Problem



Rarely is full data set available!

title: No Data, No Worries : Fabricatr
text:
Fabricatr

fabricatr - Imagine Your Data Before You Collect It



install.packages(c("fabricatr", "tidyverse"))
library(correlate)
library(dplyr)
library(fabricatr)
library(tidyr)
library(visdat)
library(nanair)

set.seed(55138)


Binary variables
Categorical/factors
Continuous
Time-Series
Correlated
Intra-Class Correlation (ICC)




Speaker Notes can be added to each slide. Formatting can be used here too.

title: No Data, No Worries : Fabricatr
text:
Basic Example



100 observations.
Binary : draw_binary().
Binomial : draw_binomial().
Continuous (0-1) : runif().
Random Normal (mean = 38, sd = 16) : rnorm().



dummy_df <- fabricatr::fabricate(
    N = 100,
    binary = fabricatr::draw_binary(
        N,
        prob = runif(N)
        ),
    binomial = fabricatr::draw_binomial(
        prob = runif(N),
        trials = 2
        ),
    uniform = runif(N),
    random_normal = rnorm(N, 38, 16)
)
dummy_df |> head()

   ID binary binomial    uniform random_normal
1 001      1        1 0.03811388      13.00777
2 002      0        0 0.43737164      65.07028
3 003      0        2 0.79656311      40.77489
4 004      1        2 0.09203046      37.34923
5 005      0        0 0.41416496      55.10216
6 006      1        0 0.27111614      35.80063





R code can be embeded and executed to produce tables and figures.

title: No Data, No Worries : Fabricatr
text:
Categorical Variables



100 observations
Random Normal (mean = 0, sd = 1) : rnorm()
Categorise using draw_ordered() and setting breaks.
Label variables with break_labels



cat_df <- fabricatr::fabricate(
    N = 100,
    x = rnorm(N),
    ordered = fabricatr::draw_ordered(
        x,
        breaks = c(-Inf,
                   -1,
                   -0.5,
                   0,
                   0.5,
                   1,
                   Inf),
        break_labels = c("Group 1",
                         "Group 2",
                         "Group 3",
                         "Group 4",
                         "Group 5",
                         "Group 6")
    )
)




R code can be embeded and executed to produce tables and figures.

title: No Data, No Worries : Fabricatr
text:
Correlated Continuous Variables
EXPERIMENTAL



100 observations
Random Normal y (mean = 38, sd = 16) : using rnorm()
Random normal a (mean = 78, sd = 14) : rnorm() rank correlation with y of 0.8 using correlate
Random normal b (mean = 46, sd = 18) : rnorm() rank correlation with y of -0.4 using correlate



corr_df <- fabricatr::fabricate(
    N = 100,
    y = rnorm(N, mean = 64, sd = 11),
    a = fabricatr::correlate(given = y,
                             rho = 0.8,
                             rnorm,
                             mean = 78,
                             sd = 14),
    b = fabricatr::correlate(given = y,
                             rho = -0.4,
                             rnorm,
                             mean = 46,
                             sd = 18)

)




R code can be embeded and executed to produce tables and figures.

title: No Data, No Worries : Fabricatr
text:
Correlated Discrete Variables
EXPERIMENTAL



100 observations
Binomial q1 (prob = 0.38, trials = 10) : using [draw_binomial()][draw_discrete]
Binomial q1 (prob = 0.63, trials = 5) : [draw_binomial()][draw_discrete] rank correlation with q1 of 0.74 using correlate
Binomial q3 (prob = 0.79, trials = 5) : [draw_binomial()][draw_discrete] rank correlation with q2 of -0.89 using correlate



corr_discrete_df <- fabricatr::fabricate(
    N = 100,
    q1 = fabricatr::draw_binomial(prob = 0.38, trials = 10, N = N),
    q2 = fabricatr::correlate(given = q1,
                             rho = 0.74,
                             fabricatr::draw_binomial,
                             prob = 0.63,
                             trials = 10),
    q3 = fabricatr::correlate(given = q2,
                             rho = -0.89,
                             fabricatr::draw_binomial,
                             prob = 0.79,
                             trials = 10)
)




R code can be embeded and executed to produce tables and figures.

title: No Data, No Worries : Fabricatr
text:
Summary

fabricatr powerful but easy to use.
Simulate data and setup analytical workflow.
Not useful for cleaning/tidying real data (~80% of work!).
Need good database schema/data dictionary




Slides : ns-rse.github.io/sheffieldr-fabricatr-20240621







 


Quarto RevealJS Template
